headline: Paramount Skydance wins Warner Bros; Netflix walks away and its shares jump
summary: Feb 26 (Reuters) - Paramount Skydance emerged as the likely winner in a months-long battle to acquire Warner Bros Discovery, after streaming giant Netflix on Thursday refused to raise its bid for the storied Hollywood studio. "We've always been disciplined, and at the price required to ‌match Paramount Skydance's latest offer, the deal is no longer financially attractive, so we are declining to match the Paramount Skydance bid," Netflix said in a ‌statement.

content.title: Paramount Skydance wins Warner Bros; Netflix walks away and its shares jump
content.summary: Feb 26 (Reuters) - Paramount Skydance emerged as the likely winner in a months-long battle to acquire Warner Bros Discovery, after streaming giant Netflix on Thursday refused to raise its bid for the storied Hollywood studio. "We've always been disciplined, and at the price required to ‌match Paramount Skydance's latest offer, the deal is no longer financially attractive, so we are declining to match the Paramount Skydance bid," Netflix said in a ‌statement.

headline: Netflix backs out of bid for Warner Bros after Paramount's new offer
summary:
STORY: Netflix said on Thursday that it was backing out of its bid to buy Warner Bros Discovery's streaming and studio assets.

It comes shortly after Warner Bros said a revised $31-per-share offer from Paramount Skydance was superior to its existing deal with Netflix.

In a statement, Netflix said (quote) "at the price required to match Paramount Skydance's latest offer, the deal is no longer financially attractive, so we are declining to match the Paramount Skydance bid." 

Netflix, which wanted to buy the Warner Bros streaming and studio businesses, agreed in December to pay $27.75 a share, saying the offer, along with a planned spinoff of Warner Bros' cable assets, would deliver a greater shareholder value.

Paramount, meanwhile, has argued it has a clearer path to U.S. regulatory approval.

On Thursday, Paramount said it welcomed Warner Bros board's unanimous reaffirmation that its bid represents the stronger offer.

content.title: Netflix backs out of bid for Warner Bros after Paramount's new offer
content.summary:
STORY: Netflix said on Thursday that it was backing out of its bid to buy Warner Bros Discovery's streaming and studio assets.

It comes shortly after Warner Bros said a revised $31-per-share offer from Paramount Skydance was superior to its existing deal with Netflix.

In a statement, Netflix said (quote) "at the price required to match Paramount Skydance's latest offer, the deal is no longer financially attractive, so we are declining to match the Paramount Skydance bid." 

Netflix, which wanted to buy the Warner Bros streaming and studio businesses, agreed in December to pay $27.75 a share, saying the offer, along with a planned spinoff of Warner Bros' cable assets, would deliver a greater shareholder value.

Paramount, meanwhile, has argued it has a clearer path to U.S. regulatory approval.

On Thursday, Paramount said it welcomed Warner Bros board's unanimous reaffirmation that its bid represents the stronger offer.

headline: Netflix Drops Warner Bros. Bid, Leaving Paramount the Winner
summary: “We’ve always been disciplined, and at the price required to match Paramount Skydance’s latest offer, the deal is no longer financially attractive,” Netflix said Thursday in a statement.  Netflix shares jumped more than 13% in after-hours trading, indicating that investors were happy to see the company walk away from the deal.  Warner Bros. fell, with investors no longer anticipating a bidding war.

content.title: Netflix Drops Warner Bros. Bid, Leaving Paramount the Winner

Warner Bros. fell, with investors no longer anticipating a bidding war.

headline: Netflix, Paramount shares jump as months-long fight for Warner Bros ends
summary: Netflix jumped more than 9% premarket on Friday as investors cheered its decision to exit the fight for Warner Bros ‌Discovery, while Paramount rose about 10% on winning the race for ‌some of the world's most prized TV and film assets.  Warner Bros shares were marginally lower.  Paramount Skydance maintained its dogged pursuit of Warner Bros, launching ‌a hostile campaign to wrest ⁠the prize from Netflix.

content.title: Netflix, Paramount shares jump as months-long fight for Warner Bros ends
content.summary: Netflix jumped more than 9% premarket on Friday as investors cheered its decision to exit the fight for Warner Bros ‌Discovery, while Paramount rose about 10% on winning the race for ‌some of the world's most prized TV and film assets.  Warner Bros shares were marginally lower.  Paramount Skydance maintained its dogged pursuit of Warner Bros, launching ‌a hostile campaign to wrest ⁠the prize from Netflix.

headline: Paramount Stock Is Rallying. Now It Can Go Head-to-Head With Netflix.
summary: Paramount Skydance  investors look like they could get a fairytale ending, with the CBS owner set to win the  Warner Bros. Discovery  bidding war.  It’s a great outcome for Paramount, which only had to raise its hostile tender offer by $1 a share to avoid a prolonged bidding war.  Paramount’s latest proposal also includes a 25 cents a share ticking fee, payable to Warner shareholders for each quarter the deal hasn’t closed after Sept. 30.

content.title: Paramount Stock Is Rallying. Now It Can Go Head-to-Head With Netflix.
content.summary: Paramount Skydance  investors look like they could get a fairytale ending, with the CBS owner set to win the  Warner Bros. Discovery  bidding war.  It’s a great outcome for Paramount, which only had to raise its hostile tender offer by $1 a share to avoid a prolonged bidding war.  Paramount’s latest proposal also includes a 25 cents a share ticking fee, payable to Warner shareholders for each quarter the deal hasn’t closed after Sept. 30.

headline: The Week in Numbers: 94% sales hike, multibillion-dollar deals
summary:
STORY: From a mega sales hike for Nvidia to multibillion-dollar deals, 

This is the Week in Numbers.

:: The Week in Numbers

:: 94% 

94% is the amount by which Nvidia’s January-quarter sales jumped. 

The chip giant posted forecast-beating revenue for the period of $68.13 billion.

It expects current quarter sales of $78 billion.

Nvidia executives told investors it had secured enough chip inventory and capacity to meet demand beyond the next several quarters.

:: $31

$31 per share was Paramount’s offer to buy Warner Bros Discovery. 

Which saw Netflix back out of its bid to buy Warner Bros Discovery's streaming and studio assets.

It said the offer from Paramount Skydance was superior to its existing deal with Netflix.

Paramount had argued it has a clearer path to U.S. regulatory approval.

:: $19 billion

A $19 billion share sale is Toyota's aim for as early as this year.  

Two sources spoke to Reuters about this strategic move…

As the automaker looks to banks and financial institutions to sell up.

It could mark a shift in Toyota’s governance reform, which remains under investor scrutiny. 

The sources said the sale figure could be larger than $19 billion depending on the willingness of shareholders to sell.

:: 50%

50% is the maximum amount Novo Nordisk will slash the U.S. prices of Ozempic and Wegovy by. 

The Danish pharma said on Tuesday that the price cuts for the blockbuster diabetes and weight-loss drugs will be effective from January next year.

And will coincide with the implementation of new, lower prices for the same drugs under federal Medicare health plans for older adults.

The market for so-called GLP-1 drugs has been getting increasingly competitive.

And both Ozempic and Wegovy will list for $675 a month.

:: $60 billion

$60 billion worth of AMD’s AI chips will be sold to Meta over the next five years. 

It’s a deal that’ll allow the Facebook owner to purchase as much as 10% of the chip firm. 

It’s AMD’s second mega chip supply deal, having signed a similar pact with OpenAI last year. 

The move was considered a vote of confidence in AMD’s chips and software, significantly boosting its stock price.

content.title: The Week in Numbers: 94% sales hike, multibillion-dollar deals

headline: Warren Buffett and the Giant Gold Cube
summary: If they gave out medals in financial trash talking,  Warren Buffett  would be on the podium.  Buffett’s most detailed takedown of gold was in Berkshire Hathaway’s 2011 shareholder letter, not long after another strong run for the yellow metal’s price.

content.title: Warren Buffett and the Giant Gold Cube
content.summary: If they gave out medals in financial trash talking,  Warren Buffett  would be on the podium.  Buffett’s most detailed takedown of gold was in Berkshire Hathaway’s 2011 shareholder letter, not long after another strong run for the yellow metal’s price.
